definition: The most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (50% of all primary CTCL), characterized by a proliferation of skin-homing malignant T-cells. It typically progresses through patch, plaque, and tumor stages over years to decades.
clinical:
Occurs mostly in older adults but can affect children. Mean duration to diagnosis is 4-6 years. Presents in photoprotected sites (buttocks, groin, abdomen, axilla). 
- Patch Stage: Large, round, well-demarcated erythematous patches with scale (variable size).
- Plaque Stage: Thicker, palpable indurated lesions.
- Tumor Stage: Exophytic nodules, often with ulceration.
Often misdiagnosed initially as psoriasis or spongiotic dermatitis.
pathogenesis: Malignant proliferation of skin-homing T-cells. Historical context: First described by Alibert Bazin (1806) who coined 'Mycosis Fungoides' due to mushroom-like tumors.
macroscopic: Large, round, well-demarcated patches or plaques in 'bathing trunk' distribution. Advanced disease presents with tumors/nodules.
microscopic:
Histology varies by stage:
- Patch Stage: Patchy, band-like (lichenoid) lymphocytic infiltrate in the papillary dermis. Fibrosis of papillary dermis. Epidermotropism (lymphocytes in epidermis) is the hallmark, seen as haloed lymphocytes, lining up at the DEJ, or Pautrier microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes). Note: Pautrier microabscesses are seen in <20% of early patch stage; classic features often absent. Lymphocytes are often small/medium and cytologically bland (not cerebriform).
- Plaque Stage: Infiltrate extends deeper into reticular dermis (beyond superficial plexus). Denser infiltrate, more developed epidermotropism.
- Tumor Stage: Diffuse sheets of atypical cells throughout the dermis. Marked cytologic atypia. Epidermotropism often lost. May resemble high-grade lymphoma or sarcoma.
ancillary_studies:
IHC: CD4+ (predominantly), loss of pan-T cell antigens (CD2, CD5, CD7) - though CD7 loss is not specific (seen in benign inflammatory conditions). 
Clonality: T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement (PCR). Identification of an identical T-cell clone in two separate biopsy sites significantly increases sensitivity and specificity.
differential_diagnosis: Psoriasis, spongiotic dermatitis (eczema), drug eruptions. In early stages, histology may be non-diagnostic (descriptive report issued: 'atypical lymphoid infiltrate').
staging: Progresses from patches to plaques to tumors. Evaluation includes full body skin exam and potential lymph node/blood assessment.
prognosis_and_prediction: Indolent course for patch/plaque stage. Tumor stage indicates more advanced disease. 50% of all primary cutaneous lymphomas.

related_figures.legend: Historical illustration of tumor stage MF (Alibert Bazin). (Time: 214s)
Clinical presentation of patches: large, round, well-demarcated lesions. (Time: 819s)
Patch stage histology: Patchy band-like infiltrate with epidermotropism. (Time: 919s)
Epidermotropism: Lymphocytes aligned along the dermal-epidermal junction. (Time: 1006s)
Pautrier microabscess: Collection of lymphocytes within the epidermis. (Time: 1037s)
Plaque stage: Dense infiltrate extending into reticular dermis. (Time: 1895s)
Tumor stage: Diffuse dermal infiltrate of atypical cells, loss of epidermotropism. (Time: 1983s)

definition: A variant of mycosis fungoides where the neoplastic T-cells show a predilection for hair follicles rather than the epidermis.
clinical:
Distinct distribution from conventional MF: affects Head and Neck (Face). 
Morphology: Acneiform lesions, rosacea-like, comedonal, or follicular-based papules/plaques. Can present as erythematous plaques with follicular prominence.
macroscopic: Acne-like or comedonal lesions on the face/scalp; follicular papules on trunk.
microscopic:
Folliculotropism: Lymphocytes infiltrating the follicular epithelium. 
Follicular Mucinosis: Mucin deposition within the follicular epithelium (dissociation of keratinocytes). 
Infiltrate: Usually small to medium-sized lymphocytes. Admixed eosinophils and plasma cells are common.
ancillary_studies: Similar to conventional MF. Mucin stains (Alcian blue) may highlight follicular mucin.
staging: Considered a distinct variant with potentially different prognostic implications compared to patch/plaque MF.
prognosis_and_prediction: Often more resistant to skin-directed therapies due to depth of infiltrate.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation on the face: Acneiform and erythematous plaques. (Time: 2134s)
Histology: Low power showing lymphocytes surrounding and infiltrating hair follicles. (Time: 2256s)
Follicular mucinosis: Mucin deposition within the follicle epithelium. (Time: 2269s)

definition: A rare variant of mycosis fungoides (Woringer-Kolopp disease) characterized by localized disease and marked epidermotropism.
clinical: Solitary patch or plaque (hyperkeratotic/verrucous). Exclusively acral distribution (extremities). Localized disease; no reports of dissemination or disease-related death.
macroscopic: Solitary, well-demarcated, scaly or verrucous plaque on the extremities.
microscopic: Marked epidermotropism ('Pagetoid scatter') of atypical lymphocytes. The epidermis is heavily infiltrated by single cells or nests. Underlying dermal infiltrate is often band-like.
ancillary_studies: IHC: Often CD8+ positive (unlike conventional MF which is usually CD4+). CD30+ cells may be present.
differential_diagnosis: Conventional MF, superficial spreading melanoma (due to pagetoid scatter), Paget's disease.

related_figures.legend: Clinical: Solitary plaques on the extremities. (Time: 2310s)
Histology: Dramatic epidermotropism (pagetoid scatter) of lymphocytes. (Time: 2319s)

definition: A rare subtype of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by the development of folds of lax skin.
clinical: Development of pendulous, loose skin folds, particularly in intertriginous areas (axilla, groin).
pathogenesis: Elastolysis leads to the clinical appearance of slack skin.
microscopic: Granulomatous infiltrate throughout the dermis. Presence of multinucleated giant cells containing engulfed elastic fibers (elastophagocytosis). Significant loss of elastic tissue. Atypical lymphocytes admixed with the granulomas.
ancillary_studies: Elastic tissue stains (Verhoeff-Van Gieson) demonstrate loss of elastic fibers.

related_figures.legend: Clinical: Redundant skin folds in the axilla. (Time: 2348s)
Histology: Granulomatous infiltrate in the dermis. (Time: 2376s)
Multinucleated histiocytes associated with the infiltrate. (Time: 2385s)

definition: A variant of MF presenting as hypopigmented macules/patches, most commonly seen in children and darker skin types.
clinical: Hypopigmented (light) spots or patches. Often in children. Not infiltrated.
pathogenesis: Cytotoxic T-cell response against melanocytes or defect in melanosome transfer.
microscopic: Features can be very subtle. Minimal spongiosis. Sparse band-like or perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate. Subtle epidermotropism (single lymphocytes in epidermis, often near the basal layer).
ancillary_studies: IHC: Predominantly CD8+ T-cell phenotype is common in this variant.
differential_diagnosis: Pityriasis alba, vitiligo, post-inflammatory hypopigmentation, leprosy.
prognosis_and_prediction: Indolent course, responds well to phototherapy.

related_figures.legend: Clinical: Child with hypopigmented patches. (Time: 2404s)
Histology: Very subtle epidermotropism; lymphocytes lining up at the DEJ. (Time: 2435s)

definition: The leukemic phase of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, defined by the triad of erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and presence of neoplastic T-cells (Sezary cells) in the skin, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood.
clinical: Erythroderma (diffuse redness and scaling >80-90% BSA). Palmoplantar hyperkeratosis/fissuring. Lymphadenopathy.
microscopic: Skin biopsy can show features of MF (band-like infiltrate, epidermotropism) but is often non-diagnostic (40% of cases) and may resemble spongiotic dermatitis or psoriasis.
ancillary_studies:
Peripheral Blood: Sezary cells (large mononuclear cells with cerebriform/serpentine nuclei on EM). 
Flow Cytometry: Expanded CD4+ population, CD4:CD8 ratio >10, loss of CD7 or CD26. 
T-cell Clonality: Identical clone in skin and blood.
differential_diagnosis: Erythrodermic psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, drug eruption, pityriasis rubra pilaris.
prognosis_and_prediction: Poor prognosis compared to MF. Aggressive disease.

related_figures.legend: Clinical: Patient with generalized erythroderma. (Time: 2447s)
Electron microscopy of a Sezary cell showing cerebriform nucleus. (Time: 362s)
Histology: Dense band-like infiltrate with some epidermotropism. (Time: 2502s)

definition: A chronic, recurrent, self-healing papulonecrotic skin eruption. It is part of the spectrum of CD30+ lymphoproliferative disorders.
clinical: Recurrent crops of small papules/nodules that may ulcerate and spontaneously regress (self-resolve) over weeks. Often mistaken for bug bites. No systemic symptoms.
pathogenesis: CD30+ lymphoproliferative disorder. Can be associated with other lymphomas (MF, ALCL, Hodgkin).
macroscopic: Small erythematous papules, nodules, or necrotic crusts.
microscopic:
Five histologic subtypes (A-E) with shared clinical behavior:
- Type A (Most Common): Wedge-shaped dermal infiltrate. Scattered large atypical CD30+ cells admixed with neutrophils, eosinophils, and histiocytes.
- Type B (Rare): Band-like infiltrate with epidermotropism (resembles MF). CD4+.
- Type C: Sheets of large atypical CD30+ cells with few admixed inflammatory cells (resembles ALCL).
- Type D: Epidermotropic infiltrate of CD8+ CD30+ cells.
- Type E: Angioinvasive/angiocentric infiltrate. Large necrotic lesions clinically.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD30+ (pattern depends on type). Type B is CD4+. Type D is CD8+.
differential_diagnosis: Arthropod bite, pityriasis lichenoides, primary cutaneous ALCL (does not self-resolve), Hodgkin lymphoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Excellent long-term prognosis, despite malignant histology ('paradoxical' disease). Low risk of progression to systemic lymphoma.

related_figures.legend: Clinical: Crops of small papules/nodules. (Time: 2618s)
Histology: Wedge-shaped infiltrate with scattered large cells. (Time: 2661s)
High power: Large atypical lymphocytes admixed with small lymphocytes and neutrophils. (Time: 2725s)
Histology: Band-like infiltrate resembling MF. (Time: 2782s)
Histology: Sheets of atypical lymphocytes (resembles ALCL). (Time: 2798s)
Clinical: Larger ulcerated lesion (angiocentric type). (Time: 2893s)

entity_name: Primary Cutaneous Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma
definition: A primary cutaneous CD30+ T-cell lymphoma composed of large atypical lymphocytes.
clinical: Solitary or localized nodules or tumors, often ulcerated. Unlike LyP, lesions persist and do not self-resolve.
pathogenesis: Primary cutaneous CD30+ LPD. Must be distinguished from systemic ALCL involving the skin.
macroscopic: Large, rapidly growing, ulcerated reddish-brown nodule or tumor.
microscopic: Diffuse, cohesive sheets of large atypical cells (anaplastic morphology) filling the dermis. High mitotic rate. Ulceration common.
ancillary_studies:
IHC: CD30+ (>75% of tumor cells). Usually CD4+. CD3 may be negative. 
Genetics: Usually ALK negative (Systemic ALCL is often ALK+, though ALK- systemic exists).
differential_diagnosis: Lymphomatoid Papulosis Type C (clinical distinction required), Systemic ALCL (requires staging), Transformation of MF.
staging: Requires full body imaging and bone marrow biopsy to rule out systemic disease.
prognosis_and_prediction: Favorable prognosis (better than systemic ALCL), though recurrence is common. 5-year survival >90%.

related_figures.legend: Histology: Diffuse sheets of large atypical lymphocytes. (Time: 2960s)
Discussion of ALK staining (usually negative in primary cutaneous forms). (Time: 3047s)
